21 September {{Death year and age|df [[Egres Abbey]] [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] Andrew II(lang-huII. András,lang-hrAndrija II.,lang-skOndrej II.,lang-ukАндрій II;circa1177spaced ndash21 September 1235), also known asAndrew of Jerusalem, wasKing of HungaryandKing of CroatiaCroatiabetween 1205 and 1235. He ruled thePrincipality of Halychfrom 1188 until 1189/1190, and again between 1208/1209 and 1210. He was the younger son ofBla III of Hungary, who entrusted him with the administration of the newly conqueredPrincipality of Halychin 1188. Andrew's rule was unpopular, and theboyarsexpelled him. Bla III willed property and money to Andrew, obliging him to lead acrusadeto theHoly Land. Instead, Andrew forced his elder brother, KingEmeric of Hungary, to cedeKingdom of Croatia (11021526)CroatiaandDalmatiaas an appanage to him in 1197. The following year, Andrew occupiedZachlumiaHum.

Despite the fact that Andrew did not stop conspiring against Emeric, the dying king made Andrew guardian of his son,Ladislaus III of HungaryLadislaus III, in 1204. After the premature death of Ladislaus, Andrew ascended the throne in 1205. According to historian Lszl Kontler, "[i]t was amindst the socio-political turmoil during [Andrew's] reign that the relations, arrangements, institutional framework and social categories that arose under Stephen I, started to disintegrate in the higher echelons of society" in Hungary.sfnKontler199975Andrew introduced a new grants policy, the so-called "new institutions", giving away money and royal estates to his partisans despite the loss of royal revenues. He was the first Hungarian monarch to adopt the title of "King of Halych andPrince of Vladimir-in-VolhyniaLodomeria". He waged at least a dozen wars to seize the twoRus' principalities, but the localboyarsand neighboring princes prevented him from conquering the principalities. He participated in theFifth Crusadeto the Holy Land in 12171218, but the crusade was a failure.

When theservientes regis, or "royal servants", rose up, Andrew was forced to issue theGolden Bull of 1222, confirming their privileges. This led to the rise of thenobility in the Kingdom of Hungary. HisDiploma Andreanumof 1224 listed the liberties of theTransylvanian Saxoncommunity. The employment ofJews in HungaryJewsandBszrmnyMuslimsto administer the royal revenues led him into conflict with theHoly Seeand the Hungarianprelates. Andrew pledged to respect the privileges of the clergymen and to dismiss his non-Christian officials in 1233, but he never fulfilled the latter promise.

Andrew's first wife,Gertrude of Merania, was murdered in 1213, because her blatant favoritism towards her German kinsmen and courtiers stirred up discontent among the native lords. The veneration of their daughter,Elizabeth of Hungary, was confirmed by the Holy See during Andrew's lifetime. After Andrew's death, his sons,Bla IV of HungaryBlaandColoman of Galicia-LodomeriaColoman, accused his third wife,Beatrice d'Este, Queen of HungaryBeatrice d'Este, of adultery and never considered her son,Stephen the PosthumousStephen, to be a legitimate son of Andrew.
article.heading: Early life
Childhood and youth (circa11771197)
article.paragraph: Andrew was the second son of KingBla III of HungaryBla IIIand Bla's first wife,Agnes of Antioch.sfnKristóMakk1996229, Appendix 4The year of Andrew's birth is not known, but modern historians agree that he was born around 1177.sfnKristóMakk1996229, Appendix 4sfnKristó199443sfnAlmási201286Andrew was first mentioned in connection to his father's invasion of thePrincipality of Halychin 1188.sfnKristóMakk1996229That year, Bla III invaded Halych upon the request of its former prince,Vladimir II Yaroslavich, who had been expelled by his subjects.sfnKristóMakk1996229sfnDimnik2003191Bla forced the new prince,Roman Mstislavich, to flee. After conquering Halych, he granted it to Andrew.sfnKristóMakk1996224sfnDimnik2003191, 193Bla also captured Vladimir Yaroslavich and imprisoned him in Hungary.sfnDimnik2003193

After Bla's withdrawal from Halych, Roman Mstislavich returned with the assistance ofRurik Rostislavich, Prince ofBelgorod Kievsky.sfnDimnik2003193They tried to expel Andrew and his Hungarian retinue, but the Hungarians routed the united forces of Mstislavich and Rostislavich.sfnDimnik2003193A group of localboyarsoffered the throne to Rostislav Ivanovich, a distant cousin of the imprisoned Vladimir Yaroslavich.sfnDimnik2003193Bla III sent reinforcements to Halych, enabling Andrew's troops to repel the attacks.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981127Andrew's reign remained unpopular in Halych, because the Hungarian soldiers insulted local women and did not respectEastern Orthodox ChurchOrthodoxchurches.sfnDimnik2003193sfnEngel200154Consequently, the local boyars allied with their former prince, Vladimir Yaroslavich, who had escaped from captivity and returned to Halych.sfnDimnik2003193–194DukeCasimir II the JustCasimir II of Polandalso supported Vladimir Yaroslavich, and they expelled Andrew and his retinue from the principality in August 1189 or 1190.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981122sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013249sfnDimnik2003193–194Andrew returned to Hungary after his defeat.sfnKristóMakk1996224He did not receive a separate duchy from his father, who only gave him estates and money.sfnKristóMakk1996224On his deathbed, Bla III, who had pledged to lead acrusadeto theHoly Land, ordered Andrew to fulfill his vow.sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013234Andrew's father died on 23 April 1196, and Andrew's older brother,Emeric, King of HungaryEmeric, succeeded him.sfnBartlČičajKohútovaLetz200230
article.heading: Duke of Croatia and Dalmatia (11971204)
article.paragraph: Andrew used the funds that he inherited from his father to recruit supporters among the Hungarian lords.sfnAlmási201286He also formed an alliance withLeopold VI, Duke of Austria, and they plotted against Emeric.sfnAlmási201286Their united troops routed the royal army atMaki, Slavonia, in December 1197.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981124Under duress, King Emeric gaveKingdom of Croatia (11021526)CroatiaandDalmatiato Andrew as an appanage.sfnCurta2006347In practice, Andrew administered Croatia and Dalmatia as an independent monarch. He minted coins, granted land and confirmed privileges.sfnCurta2006347sfnFine199422sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981124He cooperated with theHouse of FrankopanFrankopans,House of BaboniBabonii, and other local lords.sfnCurta2006347TheCanons Regular of the Holy Sepulchresettled in the province during his rule.sfnCurta2006370Taking advantage ofMiroslav of Hum's death, Andrew invadedZachlumiaHumand occupied at least the land between theCetinaandNeretvarivers.sfnFine199452He styled himself, "By the grace of God, Duke of Zadar and of all Dalmatia, Croatia and Hum" in his charters.sfnBárány2012132

Pope Innocent IIIurged Andrew to lead a crusade the Holy Land, but Andrew hatched a new conspiracy against Emeric with the help of John, Abbot of Pannonhalma,Boleslaus, Bishop of Vc, and many other prelates and lords.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981124The Pope threatened him withexcommunicationif he failed to fulfill his father's vow, but Andrew did not yield.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981124–125The conspiracy was uncovered on 10 March 1199, when King Emeric seized letters written by Andrew's partisans to Bishop Boleslaus.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981125That summer, royal troops routed Andrew's army nearLake Balaton, and Andrew fled to Austria.sfnAlmási201286sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981125A papal legate mediated a reconciliation between Andrew and Emeric, who allowed Andrew to return to Croatia and Dalmatia in 1200.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981125Andrew marriedGertrude of Merania; her father,Berthold, Duke of Merania, owned extensive domains in theHoly Roman Empirealong the borders of Andrew's duchy.sfnCurta2006347sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981125sfnKristóMakk1996230

article.paragraph: When Emeric's son,Ladislaus III of HungaryLadislaus, was born around 1200, Andrew's hopes to succeed his brother as king were shattered.sfnAlmási201286sfnKristóMakk1996230Pope Innocent confirmed the child's position as heir to the crown, declaring that Andrew's future sons would only inherit Andrew's duchy.sfnKristóMakk1996230sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981125Andrew planned a new rebellion against his brother, but King Emeric captured him without resistance nearVaradinin October 1203.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981126

template.arg: [All] the magnates of the kingdom and almost the whole of the Hungarian army deserted [King Emeric] and unlawfully sided with Duke Andrew. Very few men indeed remained with the king, and even they were terrified at the extent of the insurrection, and did not dare to urge the king to hope for success, but rather advised him to flee. Then it happened that one day both sides had drawn close to each other and were beginning to prepare themselves in earnest for {{nobr|battle. ...}} [After] much wise thought, with inspiration from heaven [King Emeric] found a successful way by which he might recover his right to the kingdom and still remain guiltless of bloodshed. So he said to his men, "Stay here a while, and do not follow me." Then he laid down his weapons, and taking only a leafy bough in his hand he walked slowly into the enemy ranks. As he passed through the midst of the armed multitude, he cried out in a loud and strong voice, "Now I shall see who will dare to raise a hand to shed the blood of the royal lineage!" Seeing him, all fell back, and not daring even to mutter, they left a wide passage for him on either side. And then when [King Emeric] reached his brother, he took him, and leading him outside the body of troops, he sent him to a certain castle for custody.
[[Thomas the Archdeacon]]: ''History of the Bishops of Salona and Split''''Archdeacon Thomas of Split: History of the Bishops of Salona and Split'' (ch. 23.), pp. 141–143.

article.paragraph: Andrew was first imprisoned in the fort ofGornji Kneginec, then inEsztergom.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981126Alexander of theHont-Pzmnyclan freed him in early 1204.sfnBartlČičajKohútovaLetz200230sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981126Having fallen ill, King Emeric had his son, Ladislaus, crowned king on 26 August.sfnEngel200189Andrew reconciled with his dying brother, who entrusted him with "the guardianship of his son and the administration of the entire kingdom until the ward should reach the age of majority",Archdeacon Thomas of Split: History of the Bishops of Salona and Split(ch. 23.), p. 143.according to the nearly contemporaneousThomas the Archdeacon.sfnAlmási201286
article.heading: His nephew's guardian (12041205)
article.paragraph: King Emeric died on 30 November 1204.sfnEngel200189Andrew governed the kingdom as Ladislaus's regent, but he counted his regnal years from the time of his brother's death, showing that he already regarded himself as the lawful monarch during Ladislaus III's reign.sfnEngel200189Pope Innocent told Andrew that he should remain loyal to Ladislaus.sfnKristóMakk1996227, 231Instead, Andrew seized the money that Emeric had deposited for Ladislaus inPilis Abbey.sfnKristóMakk1996227, 231Ladislaus's mother,Constance of Aragon, fled from Hungary, taking her son toDuchy of AustriaAustria.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981127Andrew prepared to war againstLeopold VI, Duke of Austria, but Ladislaus suddenly died inViennaon 7 May 1205.sfnKristóMakk1996227–228
article.heading: Reign
"New institutions" and campaigns in Halych (12051217)
article.paragraph: File:Andrew II of Hungary.jpgthumbrightalt=A crowned man holding a flag in his left handAndrew II depicted in ''Chronicon PictumIlluminated Chronicle''John, Archbishop of EsztergomJohn, Archbishop of Kalocsa, crowned Andrew king inSzkesfehrvron 29 May 1205.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981127sfnBartlČičajKohútovaLetz200231Andrew introduced a new policy for royal grants, which he called "new institutions" in one of his charters.sfnEngel200191sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013427He distributed large portions of the royal domainmdashroyal castles and all estates attached to themmdashas inheritable grants to his supporters, declaring that "the best measure of a royal grant is its being immeasurable."sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013427sfnEngel200191–92His "new institutions" altered the relations between the monarchs and the Hungarian lords. During the previous two centuries, a lord's status primarily depended on the income he received for his services to the monarch; after the introduction of the "new institutions", their inheritable estates yielded sufficient revenues.sfnKontler199975This policy also diminished the funds upon which the authority of theispns, or heads, of theCounty (Kingdom of Hungary)countiesmdashwho were appointed by the monarchsmdashhad been based.sfnEngel200193

During his reign, Andrew was intensely interested in the internal affairs of his former principality of Halych.sfnEngel200189He launched his first campaign to recapture Halych in 1205 or 1206.sfnEngel200189sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981127sfnDimnik2003251–253Upon the boyars' request, he intervened againstVsevolod Svyatoslavich,Prince of Chernigov, and his allies on behalf ofDaniel of GaliciaDaniel Romanovich, the child-prince of Halych, andPrince of Vladimir-in-VolhyniaLodomeria. Svyatoslavich and his allies were forced to withdraw.sfnDimnik2003253–254sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981127Andrew adopted the title of "King of Galicia and Lodomeria", demonstrating his claim to suzerainty in the two principalities.sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013441sfnCurta2006317After Andrew returned to Hungary, Vsevolod Svyatoslavich's distant cousin,Vladimir III IgorevichVladimir Igorevich, seized both Halych and Lodomeria, expelling Daniel Romanovich and his mother.sfnDimnik2003254–255, 258They fled toLeszek I of Poland, who suggested that they visit Andrew.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981127sfnDimnik2003263However, Vladimir Igorevich "sent many gifts" to both Andrew and Leszek, dissuading "them from attacking him"The Hypatian Codex II: The Galician-Volynian Chronicle(year 1207), p. 19.on behalf of Romanovich, according to theGalicianVolhynian Chronicle.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981127sfnDimnik2003263Vladimir Igorevich's rebellious brother,Roman II IgorevichRoman Igorevich, soon came to Hungary, seeking Andrew's assistance.sfnDimnik2003263Roman returned to Halych and expelled Vladimir Igorevich with the help of Hungarian auxiliary troops.sfnDimnik2003263

Andrew confirmed the liberties of two Dalmatian townsmdashSplit, CroatiaSplitandOmimdashand issued a new charter listing the privileges of theRoman Catholic Archdiocese of Split-Makarskaarchbishops of Splitin 1207.sfnBárány2012136Taking advantage of a conflict between Roman Igorevich and his boyars, Andrew sent troops to Halych under the command ofBenedict, son of Korlt.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981128Benedict captured Roman Igorevich and occupied the principality in 1208 or 1209.sfnDimnik2003263–264sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981128Instead of appointing a new prince, Andrew made Benedict governor of Halych.sfnDimnik2003264Benedict "tortured boyars and was addicted to lechery",The Hypatian Codex II: The Galician-Volynian Chronicle(year 1210), p. 20.according to theGalicianVolhynian Chronicle. The boyars offered the throne toMstislav Mstislavich,Prince of Zvenigorod, if he could overthrow Benedict.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981128Mstislav Mstislavich invaded Halych, but he could not defeat Benedict.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981128

link.part: alt=A queen reading a book and a bearded king holding a sceptre
Gertrude of Meraniaand Andrew depicted in the 13th-century ''Landgrafenpsalter'' from theLandgraviate of Thuringia

article.paragraph: Queen Gertrude's two brothers, Ekbert,Bishop of Bamberg, and Henry II, Margrave of Istria, fled to Hungary in 1208 after they were accused of participating in the murder ofPhilip of SwabiaPhilip,King of the Germans.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981128sfnKristóMakk1996233sfnEngel200190–91Andrew granted large domains to Bishop Ekbert in theSzepessgregion (nowSpi, Slovakia).sfnKristóMakk1996233Gertrude's youngest brother,Berthold (patriarch of Aquileia)Berthold, had beenArchbishop of Kalocsasince 1206; he was madeBan of CroatiaandBan of DalmatiaDalmatiain 1209.sfnKristóMakk1996232–233sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013428Andrew's generosity towards his wife's German relatives and courtiers discontented the local lords.sfnAlmási201288sfnKristóMakk1996232–234According to historian Gyula Krist, theAnonymus (chronicler)anonymous authorofGesta HungarorumThe Deeds of the Hungariansreferred to the Germans from theHoly Roman Empirewhen he sarcastically mentioned that "nobrnow ...the Romans gaze on the goods of Hungary."Anonymus, Notary of King Bla: The Deeds of the Hungarians(ch. 9), p. 27.sfnKristóMakk1996234In 1209,Zadar, whichSiege of Zadarhad been lost to the Venetians, was liberated by one of Andrew's Dalmatian vassals,Domald of Sidraga, but the Venetians recaptured the town a year later.sfnMagaš200758sfnFine1994149

Roman Igorevich reconciled with his brother, Vladimir Igorevich, in early 1209 or 1210.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981129sfnDimnik2003266Their united forces vanquished Benedict's army, expelling the Hungarians from Halych.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981129sfnDimnik2003266Vladimir Igorevich sent one of his sons, Vsevolod Vladimirovich, "bearing gifts to the king in Hungary"The Hypatian Codex II: The Galician-Volynian Chronicle(year 1211), p. 20.to appease Andrew, according to theGalicianVolhynian Chronicle.sfnDimnik2003266A group of discontented Hungarian lords offered the crown to Andrew's cousins, the sons of Andrew's uncle,Gza, son of Gza II of HungaryGza; they lived in "Greek land". However, the cousins' envoys were captured in Split in 1210.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981129sfnKristóMakk1996236In the early 1210s, Andrew sent "an army ofTransylvanian SaxonsSaxons,Vlachs,SzkelysandPechenegs" commanded by Joachim,Count of Hermannstadt, (nowSibiu, Romania) to assistBoril of Bulgaria's fight against three rebelliousCumansCumanchieftains.sfnCurta2006385sfnSpinei2009145Around the same time, Hungarian troops occupied Belgrade andBranievo (Golubac)Barancs(now Branievo, Serbia), which had been lost to Bulgaria under Emeric.sfnFine1994102sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981131Andrew's army defeated the Cumans atVidin.sfnSpinei2009145–146Andrew granted theBarcasg(nowara Brsei, Romania) to theTeutonic Knights. The Knights were to defend the easternmost regions of the Kingdom of Hungary against the Cumans and encourage their conversion to Catholicism.sfnEngel200190sfnCurta2006404

A group of boyars, who were alarmed by the despotic acts of Vladimir Igorevich, asked Andrew to restore Daniel Romanovich as ruler of Halych in 1210 or 1211.sfnDimnik2003266sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981130Andrew and his alliesmdashLeszek I of Poland and at least five Rus' princesmdashsent their armies to Halych and restored Daniel Romanovich.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981130sfnDimnik2003272Local boyars expelled Daniel Romanovich's mother in 1212.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981130She persuaded Andrew to personally lead his army to Halych.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981130He captured Volodislav Kormilchich, the most influential boyar, and took him to Hungary.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981130After Andrew withdrew from Halych, the boyars again offered the throne to Mstislav Mstislavich, who expelled Daniel Romanovich and his mother from the principality.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981130Andrew departed for a new campaign against Halych in summer 1213.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981130During his absence, Hungarian lords who were aggrieved at Queen Gertrude's favoritism towards her German entourage captured and murdered her and many of her courtiers in thePilis Hillson 28 September.sfnEngel200191sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981130sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013429When he heard of her murder, Andrew returned to Hungary and ordered the execution of the murderer,Peter, son of Tre.sfnEngel200191However, Peter's accomplices, includingPalatine of HungaryPalatineBnk Br-Kaln, did not receive severe punishments.sfnEngel200191sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013429A group of Hungarian lords, whom Andrew called "perverts" in one of his letters, was plotting to dethrone Andrew and crown his eldest son, the eight-year-oldBla IV of HungaryBla, but they failed to dethrone him and could only force Andrew to consent to Bla's coronation in 1214.sfnEngel200194sfnAlmási201289

Andrew and Leszek of Poland signed a treaty of alliance, which obliged Andrew's second son,Coloman of Galicia-LodomeriaColoman, to marry Leszek of Poland's daughter,Salomea of PolandSalomea.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981131Andrew and Leszek jointly invaded Halych in 1214, and Coloman was made prince. He agreed to cedePrzemylto Leszek of Poland.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981131sfnKristóMakk1996236The following year, Andrew returned to Halych and capturedPrzemyl.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981131Leszek of Poland soon reconciled with Mstislav Mstislavich; they jointly invaded Halych and forced Coloman to flee to Hungary.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981131A new officer of state, themaster of the treasurytreasurer, was responsible for the administration of the royal chamber from around 1214 onwards.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981131sfnEngel200192However, royal revenues had significantly diminished.sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013427Upon the advice of the treasurer,Denis, son of Ampud, Andrew imposed new taxes andFarm (revenue leasing)farmed out royal incomefrom minting, salt trade and custom duties.sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013427–428sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981131The yearly exchange of coins also produced more revenue for the royal chamber.sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013428However, these measures provoked discontent in Hungary.sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013428

Andrew signed a new treaty of alliance with Leszek of Poland in the summer of 1216.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981132Leszek and Andrew's son, Coloman, invaded Halych and expelled Mstislav Mstislavich and Daniel Romanovich, after which Coloman was restored.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981132That same year, Andrew metStephen Nemanji,Grand Prince of Serbia, inuprijaRavno(nowuprija, Serbia).sfnBárány2012143sfnFine1994105–106He persuaded Stephen Nemanji to negotiate withHenry of FlandersHenry,Latin EmperorLatin Emperor of Constantinople, who was the uncle of Andrew's second wife,Yolanda de Courtenay.sfnBárány2012143sfnFine1994105–106Stephen Nemanji was crowned king of Serbia in 1217.sfnFine1994108Andrew planned to invade Serbia, but Stephen Nemanji's brother,Saint SavaSava, dissuaded him, according to both versions of theLife of Sava.sfnBárány2012143sfnFine1994108
article.heading: Andrew's crusade (12171218)
article.paragraph: File:The fifth crusade.jpgthumbrightalt=A horseman with a flag depicting a two-barred crossAndrew at the head of hisFifth Crusadecrusader army(from the ''Illuminated Chronicle'')In July 1216, the newly electedPope Honorius IIIonce again called upon Andrew to fulfill his father's vow to lead a crusade.sfnBárány2013462Andrew, who had postponed the crusade at least three times (in 1201, 1209 and 1213), finally agreed.sfnVan Cleve1969387sfnRunciman1989b146Steven Runciman, Tibor Almsi and other modern historians say that Andrew hoped that his decision would increase his likelihood of being elected as Latin Emperor of Constantinople, because his wife's uncle, Emperor Henry, had died in June.sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013441sfnRunciman1989b146sfnAlmási201287According to a letter written by Pope Honorius in 1217, envoys from theLatin Empirehad actually informed Andrew that they planned to elect either him or his father-in-law,Peter II of CourtenayPeter of Courtenay, as emperor.sfnBárány2013463-465The barons of the Latin Empire elected Peter of Courtenay in the summer of 1216.sfnRunciman1989b146sfnAlmási201287–88sfnBárány2013463

Andrew sold and mortgaged royal estates to finance his campaign, which became part of the widerFifth Crusade.sfnVan Cleve1969387He renounced his claim to Zadar in favor of the Republic of Venice so that he could secure shipping for his army.sfnMagaš200758sfnVan Cleve1969387He entrusted Hungary to Archbishop John of Esztergom, and gave Croatia and Dalmatia toPontius de Cruce, theKnights TemplarTemplarPrior of Vrana.sfnVan Cleve1969387In July 1217, Andrew departed fromZagreb, accompanied byLeopold VI of AustriaandOtto I, Duke of Merania.sfnVan Cleve1969387–388sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981133His army was so largemdashat least 10,000 mounted soldiers and uncountable infantrymenmdashthat most of it stayed behind when Andrew and his men embarked in Split two months later.sfnVan Cleve1969387–388sfnRunciman1989b147–148sfnRichard1999297The ships transported them toAcre, IsraelAcre, where they landed in October.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981133

The leaders of the crusade includedJohn of Brienne,King of Jerusalem, Leopold of Austria, theGrand Master of the Knights HospitallerGrand Masters of the Hospitallers, theGrand Masters of the Knights TemplarTemplarsand theGrand Masters of the Teutonic KnightsTeutonic Knights. They held a war council in Acre, with Andrew leading the meeting.sfnSterns1985358In early November, the crusaders launched a campaign for theJordan River, forcingAl-Adil II,Sultan of Egypt, to withdraw without fighting; the crusaders then pillagedBeisan.sfnVan Cleve1969390sfnRunciman1989b148After the crusaders returned to Acre, Andrew did not participate in any other military actions.sfnVan Cleve1969393sfnRunciman1989b148–149Instead, he was collectingrelics, including a water jug allegedly used at themarriage at Cana, the heads ofSaint StephenandMargaret the Virgin, the right hands of the ApostlesThomas the ApostleThomasandBartholomew the ApostleBartholomewand a part ofAaron's rod.sfnRunciman1989b148–149If Thomas the Archdeacon's report of certain "evil and audacious men" in Acre who "treacherously passed him a poisoned drink"Archdeacon Thomas of Split: History of the Bishops of Salona and Split(ch. 25.), p. 165.is reliable, Andrew's inactivity was because of illness.sfnVan Cleve1969393

Andrew decided to return home at the very beginning of 1218, even thoughRaoul of Merencourt,Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem, threatened him with excommunication.sfnRichard1999298sfnVan Cleve1969388, 393Andrew first visitedTripoli, LebanonTripoliand participated in the marriage ofBohemond IV of AntiochandMelisende of Lusignanon 10 January.sfnVan Cleve1969393From Tripoli, he travelled toArmenian Kingdom of CiliciaCilicia, where he andLeo I, King of ArmeniaLeo I of Armeniabetrothed Andrew's youngest son,Andrew of Hungary, Prince of HalychAndrew, and Leo's daughter,Isabella, Queen of ArmeniaIsabella.sfnVan Cleve1969393sfnKristóMakk1996238Andrew proceeded through theSeldjukSultanate of Rumbefore arriving inNicaea(nowznik, Turkey).sfnVan Cleve1969393His cousins (the sons of his uncle, Gza) attacked him when he was in Nicaea.sfnKristóMakk1996238He arranged the marriage of his oldest son, Bla, toMaria Laskarina, a daughter of EmperorTheodore I Laskaris.sfnKristóMakk1996238When he arrived in Bulgaria, Andrew was detained until he "gave full surety that his daughter would be united in marriage"toIvan Asen II of Bulgaria, according to Thomas the Archdeacon.sfnBárány2012148sfnFine1994129Andrew returned to Hungary in late 1218.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981133Andrew's "crusade had achieved nothing and brought him no honor", according to historian Thomas C. Van Cleve.sfnVan Cleve1969394Oliver of Padernborn,James of Vitryand other 13th-century authors blamed Andrew for the failure of crusade.sfnVan Cleve1969394
article.heading: Golden Bull (12181222)
article.paragraph: File:Aranybulla1.jpgthumbrightalt=A manuscript with a seal attached to itTheGolden Bull of 1222When he returned to Hungary, Andrew complained to Pope Honorius that his kingdom was "in a miserable and destroyed state, deprived of all of its revenues."sfnEngel200154A group of barons had even expelled Archbishop John from Hungary.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981133Andrew was in massive debt because of his crusade, which forced him to impose extraordinarily high taxes and debase coinage.sfnEngel200154In 1218 or 1219, Mstislav Mstislavich invaded Halych and captured Andrew's son, Coloman.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981134sfnDimnik2003289–290Andrew compromised with Mstislavich. Coloman was released, and Andrew's youngest son and namesake was betrothed to Mstislavich's daughter.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981134In 1220, a group of lords persuaded Andrew to make his eldest son, Bla, the Duke of Croatia, Dalmatia and Slavonia.sfnKristóMakk1996238sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013425

Andrew employedJews in HungaryJewsandBszrmnyMuslimsto administer royal revenues, which caused a discord between Andrew and the Holy See starting in the early 1220s.sfnEngel200196–97sfnBerend2006152Pope Honorius urged Andrew and Queen Yolanda to prohibit Muslims from employing Christians.sfnBerend2006152Andrew confirmed the privileges of clergymen, including their exemption from taxes andPrivilegium foritheir right to be exclusively judged by church courts, but also prohibited theconsecrationofudvornici,castle folk (Kingdom of Hungary)castle folkand other serfs in early 1222.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981135sfnBartlČičajKohútovaLetz200230–31However, a new conflict emerged between Andrew and the Holy See after he persuaded Bla to separate from his wife, Maria Laskarina.sfnBárány2012150An "immense crowd" approached Andrew around June 1222, demanding "grave and unjust things", according to a letter of Pope Honorius.sfnEngel200194Actually, theRoyal servant (Kingdom of Hungary)royal servantsmdashwho were landowners directly subject to the monarch's power and obliged to fight in the royal armymdashassembled, forcing Andrew to dismissJulius I KnJulius Knand his other officials. Andrew was also forced issue a royal charter, theGolden Bull of 1222.sfnEngel200185, 94The charter summarized the liberties of the royal servants, including their exemption from taxes and the jurisdiction of theispns.sfnEngel200194sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013428–429The last clause of the Golden Bull authorized "the bishops as well as the other barons and nobles of the realm, singularly and in common" to resist the monarch if he did not honor the provisions of the charter.sfnEngel200194sfnBerendUrbańczykWiszewski2013429The Golden Bull clearly distinguished the royal servants from the king's other subjects, which led to the rise of theHungarian nobility.sfnEngel200194The Golden Bull is commonly compared with England'sMagna Cartaa similar charter which was sealed a few years earlier in 1215.sfnErtman1997273A significant difference between them is that, in England, the settlement strengthened the position of all the royal subjects but, in Hungary, the aristocracy came to dominate both the crown and the lower orders.sfnErtman1997273–4
article.heading: Conflicts with his son and the Church (12221234)
article.paragraph: Andrew discharged PalatineTheodore Csandand restored Julius Kn in the second half of 1222.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981137The following year, Pope Honorius urged Andrew to launch a new crusade.sfnBárány2012151If the report of theContinuatio Claustroneuburgensisis reliable, Andrew took the cross to show that he intended launch a new crusade, but no other sources mention this event.sfnBárány2012151Andrew planned to arrange a new marriage for his eldest son, Bla, but Pope Honorius mediated a reconciliation between Bla and his wife in the autumn of 1223.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981137sfnBárány2012150This angered Andrew, and Bla fled to Austria. He returned in 1224, after the bishops persuaded Andrew to forgive him.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981137

In hisDiploma Andreanumof 1224, Andrew confirmed the privileges of the "Transylvanian SaxonsSaxons" who inhabited the region ofHermannstadtin southern Transylvania (nowSibiu, Romania).sfnCurta2006403sfnEngel2001114The following year, he launched a campaign against the Teutonic Knights, who had attempted to eliminate his suzerainty. The Knights were forced to leaveBarcasgand the neighboring lands.sfnCurta2006403sfnSpinei2009147Andrew's envoys and Leopold VI of Austria signed a treaty on 6 June, which ended the armed conflicts along the Hungarian-Austrian border. As part of the treaty, Leopold VI paid an indemnification for the damages that his troops had caused in Hungary.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981138Andrew made his oldest son, Bla,Duke of Transylvania. Bla's former duchy was given to Andrew's second son, Coloman, in 1226.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981138Duke Bla started expanding his suzerainty over theCumans, who inhabited the lands east of the Carpathian Mountains.sfnCurta2006405–405sfnEngel200195Andrew launched a campaign against Mstislav Mstislavich in 1226, because the latter refused to grant Halych to Andrew's youngest son despite a previous compromise.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981138Andrew besieged and capturedPrzemyl,Terebovl, and other fortresses in Halych.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981138However, his troops were routed atKremenetsand Zvenigorod, forcing him to withdraw.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981138Despite his victories, Mstislavich ceded Halych to Andrew's son in early 1227.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981138

link.part: alt=A crowned man holding a sealed document

article.paragraph: In 1228, Andrew authorized his son, Bla, to revise his previous land grants.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981139Pope Honorius also supported Bla's efforts.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981139Bla confiscated the domains of two noblemen,Simon Kacsicsand Bnk Br-Kaln, who had taken part in the conspiracy to murder Queen Gertrude.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981139In 1229, upon Bla's proposal, Andrew confirmed the privileges of the Cuman chieftains who had subjected themselves to Bla.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981140Robert, Archbishop of Esztergom, made a complaint about Andrew to the Holy See, because Andrew continued to employ Jews and Muslims.sfnBerend2006155Pope Gregory IXauthorized the archbishop to perform acts of religious censure to persuade Andrew to dismiss his non-Christian officials.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981141Under duress, Andrew issued a new Golden Bull in 1231, which confirmed that Muslims were banned from employment, and empowered the Archbishop of Esztergom to excommunicate the king if he failed to honor the provisions of the new Golden Bull.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981141sfnEngel200194sfnBerend2006154–155In the second half of the year, Andrew invaded Halych and restored his youngest son, Andrew, to the throne.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981141

Archbishop Robert excommunicated Palatine Denis and put Hungary under aninterdicton 25 February 1232, because the employment of Jews and Muslims continued despite the Golden Bull of 1231.sfnBerend2006157sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981142Since the archbishop accused the Muslims of persuading Andrew to seize church property, Andrew restored properties to the archbishop, who soon suspended the interdict.sfnBerend2006157sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981142Upon Andrew's demand, Pope Gregory sent CardinalGiacomo Pecorariaas his legate to Hungary and promised that nobody would be excommunicated without the pope's special authorization.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981142Although Andrew departed for Halych to support his youngest son in a fight against Daniel Romanivich, he continued his negotiations with the papal legate.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981143On 20 August 1233, in the forests ofBereg CountyBereg, he vowed that he would not employ Jews and Muslims to administrate royal revenues, and would pay 10,000 marks as compensation for usurped Church revenues.sfnEngel200194sfnBerend2006158–159Andrew repeated his oath inEsztergomin September.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981143

Andrew andFrederick II, Duke of Austria, signed a peace treaty in late 1233.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981143Andrew, who had been widowed, married the 23-year-oldBeatrice d'Este, Queen of HungaryBeatrice D'Esteon 14 May 1234, even though his sons were sharply opposed to his third marriage.sfnKristóMakk1996243John, Bishop of Bosnia, put Hungary under a new interdict in the first half of 1234, because Andrew had not dismissed his non-Christian officials despite his oath of Bereg.sfnBerend2006160sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981144Andrew and Archbishop Robert of Esztergom protested against the bishop's act at the Holy See.sfnBerend2006160
article.heading: Last years (12341235)
article.paragraph: Danilo Romanovich laid siege to Halych, and Andrew's youngest son died during the siege in the autumn of 1234.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981144However, Andrew stormed Austria in the summer of 1235, forcing Duke Frederick to pay an indemnification for damages that his troops had caused while raiding Hungary.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981144Upon Andrew's demand, Pope Gregory declared on 31 August that Andrew and his sons could only be excommunicated by the authorization of the Holy See.sfnÉrszegiSolymosi1981144Andrew died on 21 September,sfnEngel200198and was buried inEgres Abbey.sfnKristóMakk1996244

article.paragraph: Andrew's first wife, Gertrude of Merania, was born around 1185, according to historian Gyula Krist.sfnKristóMakk1996231Their first child,Anna Maria of HungaryMary, was born in 1203 or 1204. She became the wife of Ivan Asen II of Bulgaria.sfnKristóMakk1996232, Appendix 4Andrew's eldest son,Bla IV of HungaryBla, was born in 1206. He later succeeded his father as king.sfnKristóMakk1996232, Appendix 4Bla's younger sister,Elizabeth of HungaryElisabeth, was born in 1207. She marriedLouis IV, Landgrave of Thuringia.sfnKristóMakk1996232, Appendix 4She died in 1231 and wasCanonizationcanonizedduring Andrew's life.sfnEngel200197Andrew's second son, Coloman, was born in 1208. His third son, Andrew, was born around 1210. Coloman and Andrew each ruled the Principality of Halych for a short period.sfnKristóMakk1996232, Appendix 4

Two years after his first wife was murdered, Andrew married Yolanda de Courtenay, who was born around 1198.sfnKristóMakk1996236–237Their only child,Violant of HungaryYolanda, was born around 1219 and marriedJames I of Aragon.sfnKristóMakk1996Appendix 4Andrew's third wife, Beatrice D'Este, was about twenty-three when they married in 1234.sfnKristóMakk1996243, Appendix 4She gave birth to a son,Stephen the PosthumousStephen, after Andrew's death.sfnKristóMakk1996243, 282, Appendix 4However, Andrew's two older sons, Bla and Coloman, accused her of adultery and considered her child to be a bastard.sfnKristóMakk1996282Her grandson,Andrew III of HungaryAndrew, became the last monarch of theHouse of rpd.sfnKristóMakk1996282
